{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-254-02-B |Item_parent=Nutritional needs of pregnant women |Item_parent_short=Nutritional needs of pregnant women |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the expected weight gain during pregnancy |Description=Based on BMI at conception |Rubric=Physiopathology |Contributors= |Order=2}} The average increase in weight during pregnancy is 13 kg. A weight gain of 1 kg per month during the first two trimesters and 500 g per week during the last trimester is considered normal. However, the expected weight gain depends on the body type.
{| class="wikitable" |BMI before pregnancy |Recommended weight gain during pregnancy |- |IMC < 18.5 kg/m²²) |12.5 - 18 kg |- |18.5 kg/m2 < BMI ≤ 25.0 kg/m2 |11.5 - 16 kg |- | 25.0 kg/m2 < BMI ≤ 30.0 kg/m² - | 7 - 11.5 kg/m2 |7 - 11.5 kg |- |BMI ≥ 30.0 kg/m2 |5 - 9 kg |}

question.title: What is the average increase in weight during pregnancy?

option_a.title: 12 kg
option_a.description: A weight gain of 1 kg per month during the first two trimesters and 500 g per week during the last trimester is not considered normal

option_b.title: 13 kg
option_b.description: A weight gain of 1 kg per month during the first two trimesters and 500 g per week during the last trimester is considered normal

option_c.title: 15 kg
option_c.description: The recommended weight gain varies depending on the body type, but 15 kg is a general estimate

option_d.title: 16 kg
option_d.description: The recommended weight gain during pregnancy is the same for all women, regardless of their BMI
